column4: Can anyone see anything wrong with this when trying to use it on a currently mounted ext3 partition? "sudo mount -o remount,umask=0000 /media/Backup1"
I'm not an expert but that line looks to me like you ar trying to mount an already mounted drive
no I mean   mount then remount ,  try unmount then remount
If I unmounted it then I would just "mount" it, you can't remount something that isn't mounted. The whole reason I'm using remount is to avoid having to first unmount it!
whn you are compiling from source you often need the  -dev package of the dependency
... I'm not compiling anything, I'm trying to watch a damn DVD
try installing a dev package anyway and while you are in synaptic  reinstall the other one
there is another package needed for dvd
I've installed it, I've installed all of them
ok then you probably won'T benifit from resintalling and perhaps solving your problem
How can I not benefit from solving my problem, that makes no sense
I have everything installed on there that it recommends
I am suggesting that you RE-install everything recommended,  and a reboot might not hurt either
rebooting clears the memory of zombies and everything
It's nothing to do with that, he just set the wrong drive/partiton
